title: Lynne Boddy
text:
Lynne Boddy is a Professor of <a href="Microbial%20ecology">Microbial Ecology</a> at <a href="Cardiff%20University">Cardiff University</a>. She works on the ecology of wood decomposition, including <a href="synecology">synecology</a> and <a href="autecology">autecology</a>. She won the 2018 <a href="Learned%20Society%20of%20Wales">Learned Society of Wales</a> Frances Hoggan Medal.
Early life and education.
Boddy studied <a href="biology">biology</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Exeter">University of Exeter</a>. She became interested in mycology because she was taught by the notable mycologist <a href="John%20Webster%20%28mycologist%29">John Webster</a> and encountered the fungus Serpula lacrimans causing dry rot in her student accommodation. She joined <a href="Queen%20Mary%20College">Queen Mary College</a> as a research assistant working on the decay of wood. Here she was the local organiser of a symposium on Decomposer <a href="Basidiomycota">Basidiomycetes</a>. She earned a <a href="PhD">PhD</a> in <a href="ecology">ecology</a> from <a href="Queen%20Mary%20University%20of%20London">Queen Mary University of London</a> and a <a href="Doctor%20of%20Science">Doctor of Science</a> DSc degree in the ecology of wood composition from the <a href="University%20of%20Exeter">University of Exeter</a>. She worked under the supervision of Mike Swift.
Research and career.
Boddy was appointed a <a href="postdoctoral%20researcher">postdoctoral researcher</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Bath">University of Bath</a>. Boddy subsequently joined <a href="Cardiff%20University">Cardiff University</a> in 1983, where she worked on antagonistic interactions, <a href="Mycelium">mycelia</a> and fungal communities. Fungal communities impact the decay rate of wood. She studied how <a href="neural%20network">neural network</a>s could be used to analyse <a href="flow%20cytometry">flow cytometry</a> data from <a href="phytoplankton">phytoplankton</a>. She is interested in how fungi fight with each other as they investigate the forest floor. Boddy identified that fungi battle each other by producing inhibitory chemicals that can be transmitted through the air, equivalent to the <a href="poisonous%20gas">poisonous gas</a> produced during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>. Her research on fighting fungi was featured in <a href="New%20Scientist">New Scientist</a>.
Boddy leads the Fungal Ecology Group at <a href="Cardiff%20University">Cardiff University</a>. She looked at the decomposition of <a href="coarse%20woody%20debris">coarse woody debris</a>. Boddy has studied the role of fungi in <a href="Carbon%20cycle">carbon</a> and <a href="Nutrient%20cycle">nutrient cycling</a>. Boddy has studied <a href="priority%20effect">priority effect</a>s during the establishment of fungal communities in wood. She found that abiotic variables impact the fungal interactions of beech wood, and that fungal combative abilities were sensitive to the ambient temperature. She demonstrated that differences in the <a href="Abiotic%20component">abiotic</a> factors between sites can cause variation in the impact of <a href="priority%20effect">priority effect</a>s in wood decay communities. In 2008 Boddy argued in <a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a> that fungi were humankind's most invaluable species. She claims that without fungi, land-based ecosystems, including humans, would not exist.
Public engagement.
Boddy has presented fungi on the television and radio. She contributed to the film "Superfungi: Will fungi help save the world?." She served as President of the <a href="British%20Ecological%20Society">British Ecological Society</a> in 2009. She founded the <a href="British%20Mycological%20Society">British Mycological Society</a> Fungus Day, which is held annually in October to highlight the importance of fungi in ecosystems. Her outreach highlights the role of fungal <a href="mycorrhiza">mycorrhiza</a> in plant health and the impact amateurs and enthusiasts can have on advancing understanding of mycological diversity. In 2009 Boddy was part of a <a href="gold%20medal">gold medal</a> winning stand at the <a href="RHS%20Chelsea%20Flower%20Show">RHS Chelsea Flower Show</a>. She led the steering committee for the <a href="Royal%20Botanic%20Garden%20Edinburgh">Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh</a> exhibition "From Another Kingdom". Boddy was part of a science <a href="opera">opera</a> which was performed at the <a href="Green%20Man%20Festival">Green Man Festival</a> in 2017. The performance included Boddy's research into the <a href="Wood-Wide%20Web">Wood-Wide Web</a>. In 2016 Boddy was profiled on <a href="The%20Life%20Scientific">The Life Scientific</a>. She delivered the 2018 <a href="Cardiff%20University">Cardiff University</a> <a href="International%20Women%27s%20Day">International Women's Day</a> lecture.
Honours and awards.
Boddy was appointed <a href="Member%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">Member of the Order of the British Empire</a> (MBE) in the <a href="2019%20Birthday%20Honours">2019 Birthday Honours</a> for services to mycology and public engagement in science.
